Other rare inflammatory or autoimmune conditions
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)

justification: Presents with fever, rash, extremity changes (edema, erythema), conjunctivitis, and mucosal involvement like strawberry tongue (erythema). Leukocytosis and sterile pyuria are common laboratory findings.}, {diagnosis: Scarlet fever

justification: Caused by group A Streptococcus, it features fever, sore throat, strawberry tongue, and a characteristic sandpaper-like rash. Leukocytosis is common, and pyuria may occur if theres co-existing urinary tract infection.}, {diagnosis: Systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (sJIA)

justification: Autoimmune disease causing fever, rash, arthritis, and often leukocytosis. Hand edema can be seen with joint inflammation, and pyuria might indicate associated inflammation or secondary infection.}, {diagnosis: Stevens-Johnson syndrome/Toxic epidermal necrolysis (SJS/TEN)

justification: Severe mucocutaneous reactions (often drug-induced) characterized by fever, widespread painful erythematous rash, and mucosal involvement. Leukocytosis and sterile pyuria can be present.}, {diagnosis: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)

justification: Delayed hypersensitivity reaction to drugs, often presenting with fever, rash, facial edema, lymphadenopathy, and internal organ involvement. Leukocytosis, eosinophilia, and atypical lymphocytosis are common. Pyuria could reflect renal involvement.}, {diagnosis: Leptospirosis

justification: Bacterial infection spread through animal urine, causing fever, headache, muscle pain, and rash. Conjunctival suffusion is common, and aseptic meningitis can occur. Leukocytosis and pyuria are possible.}, {diagnosis: Infectious mononucleosis (Epstein-Barr virus)

justification: Viral infection characterized by fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, and fatigue. A rash, especially after amoxicillin use, can occur. Leukocytosis with atypical lymphocytes is typical, and mild hepatitis can lead to transient sterile pyuria.}, {diagnosis: Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD)

justification: Common viral infection causing fever, mouth sores, and a rash on the hands and feet. While not typical, hand edema could occur with severe cases. Pyuria is usually not present.}, {diagnosis: Measles

justification: Highly contagious viral illness with fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and a characteristic maculopapular rash. Leukopenia is more common than leukocytosis, and pyuria is not typical.}, {diagnosis: Viral exanthem

justification: A wide range of viruses can cause fever and rash in children. Hand edema and pyuria are not specific features, but may be present depending on the underlying virus and individual reaction.}
